 Education Rehabilitation Project ii REPUBLIC OF TOGO EDUCATION REHABILITATION PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Republic of Togo Implementing Agency: Ministry of National Education and Scientific Research (MENRS) Beneficiaries: Primary and secondary school students under the aegis of the Ministry of National Education and Scientific Research Credit Amount: SDR 23.3 million (US$36.6 million equivalent) Terms: Standard IDA terms with 40 years Project Objectives: This operation is designed to reverse the rapid deterioration in the education sector in Togo following several years of social and political unrest and a decade of declining enrollment and quality. It is based on priorities described in the Govermment's Letter of Education Sector Policy. The project has two objectives: (a) to improve the quality of schools; and (b) to develop better education system management. Project Description: The project's support to the implementation of the education sector strategy would be provided through two components: 1. The project would support the development of better schools through: (a) school construction and rehabilitation; (b) provision of textbooks; and (c) the Quality Schools Initiative. 2. The project would support the development of better education system management through: (a) decentralized recruitment and financing of teachers; and (b) development of system management tools including: (i) information and communication systems; (ii) budgetary programming and monitoring; and (iii) consolidation of the ministerial restructuring by strengthening decision-making processes and further decentralizing the responsibility for instructional as well as financial management. Benefits: The main benefits of the proposed project will be improved education quality and access as a result of a more adequate supply of primary school teachers, rebuilding of infrastructure badly damaged by recent vandalism and neglect, and greater availability of pedagogic materials at the primary and secondary
 Education Rehabilitation Project iii school levels. The institutional capacity building carried out under the project will be an essential step for ensuring the presence of teachers in classrooms and for reversing declining enrollment trends. The establishment of consultative regional school boards and a region-based Education Support Fund will present the potential for a significant reduction in unit salary costs as well as a corresponding opportunity for increasing the number of teachers in place and for reallocating the sectoral budget in favor of needed non- salary operating expenditures. Risks: The main risks of the project are the politically unstable environment which could significantly increase the likelihood of implementation delays and difficulties in assuring adequate budgetary resources to finance Government's counterpart contribution including payment of auxiliary teachers. Other risks to achievement of project objectives are Government's capacity to address broad institutional, finance and political issues critical to the success of the reform program and low sectoral capacity to oversee the Quality Schools Initiative on an ongoing basis. The risks presented by the politically unstable environment are addressed to some extent in project design, with an emphasis on working teams supported by coordinated short- term interventions of external expertise. Budgetary issues are addressed through up-front agreement on budget targets that are included in Government's Letter of Education Sector Policy and that will be monitored through a planned Public Expenditure Review, and annual budget reviews. The Government's commitment to address institutional capacity issues has been expressed through its Letter of Education Sector Policy which includes specific institutional reform targets; these would be closely monitored throughout project implementation. The issue of low sectoral capacity to oversee the Quality Schools Initiative would be addressed through the use of short-term consultancies to provide training and research experience to Ministry and University of Benin personnel, who would in turn provide training to inspectors and pedagogic counselors on an ongoing basis. The Quality Schools Initiative would over the long term shift responsibility for in- service training to the schools and prefectures and away from the current unproductive centralized approach.

 Education Rehabilitation Project 1 REPUBLIC OF TOGO EDUCATION REHABILITATION PROJECT L INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of Togo has requested IDA's assistance to finance a five-year Education Rehabilitation Project. This project is designed to reverse the decline in education sector net enrollment and quality. It addresses primarily short-term needs arising from the 1992-93 general strike, while rebuilding the sector in a way that is consistent with sectoral policy and medium- and long-term development objectives. It will also put in place mechanisms to facilitate the implementation of key features of this strategy, notably the decentralization of education management and finance. This operation would be the first phase of two education sector operations planned to implement broad-based sector reform. The second operation would accelerate development of the education system by further strengthening school-level teaching and learning processes and reinforcing the sustainability of sector financing, and decentralized management. 1.2 The Bank's previous involvement in the education sector in Togo includes two general education projects, now closed (Cr. 101 8-TO, Cr. 1568-TO), and an ongoing Technical Education and Vocational Training Project (Cr. 2174-TO). The latter aims at restructuring and decentralizing the VET system through a national training fund to make it employment oriented and responsive to the skill demands of Togo's private sector. The results of these projects have underscored the need to closely monitor the broad policy and institutional environment and to focus on issues of implementation. Experience has demonstrated that meeting specific resource needs will be insufficient to bring about either sustainable improvement in teaching and learning outcomes that require the availability of personnel, basic materials and equipment, or regional and gender equity, in the absence of complementary measures designed to strengthen planning and management capacity, reorient incentives, and redefine policies and operational strategies. The Education Rehabilitation Project is designed to address these issues. 1.3 The Country Assistance Strategy for Togo assigns a high priority to the strategy and activities envisaged under the project in support of the central role that human resource development must play in the economic renaissance of the country. The Country Assistance Strategy stresses that the development of education sector policy must be pursued within a difficult macroeconomic framework. Sectoral policy should hence be monitored closely and developed further over the life of the project. Project preparation has been a broadly participative process, and the supervision of the project would include annual review meetings and a mid-term review with representation of all stakeholders involved in the sector as well as beneficiary assessments.
 Education Rehabilitation Project 2 II. SECTORAL CONTEXT A. Background 2.1 Togo is a low-income country with an estimated per capita GNP of US$315 in 1994 and a population of 3.9 mnillion that is rapidly growing at an annual rate of 3.1 percent. The economy has traditionally depended on primary production, service activities and exports of phosphates and cotton. Agricultural production is concentrated in food crops, cotton, coffee and cocoa. About 75 percent of the active population is employed in agriculture which accounts for about 38 percent of GDP. The service sector consists mainly of commerce and transit activities. 2.2 As a result of favorable trends in primary commodity prices, facilitated by political stability, the Togolese economy experienced almost two decades of uninterrupted real growth in excess of 5 percent per annum through the late 1970s. During the period 1974-78, however, growth increasingly stemmed from an excessive and externally-financed expansion of the public sector, leading to increasing external and intemal financial imbalances and mounting structural rigidities. A partial stabilization program was launched in 1979, but after four years of stagnating economic activity and continual financial problems, the Togolese Government recognized the need for a more comprehensive recovery policy. 2.3 In response, the first in a series of structural adjustment programs was launched in 1983. These programs have all been supported by the IMF and by the Bank, most recently through SAL IV which was approved by the Board in December 1990. The thrust of these programs has been to reduce the external and internal financial imbalances, cut back the Government's role in the economy while improving its efficiency in using public resources, and improve the incentives framework for private sector activities. Until early 1991, substantial progress was achieved in implementing the structural reforms, while significantly reducing the internal and external financial imbalances. During the period 1984-89, Togo was considered as one of the best economic performers in Western Africa, with real GDP growth of 3.4 percent p.a. on average. B. Recent Developments 2.4 Political Developments. A deep political crisis was precipitated in 1991, when the regime came under increasing pressure to establish a multi-party system. This interrupted Togo's successful economic recovery of the 1980s. The period was marred by violent street riots and mass civil disobedience. A national conference, convened in July 1991, led to the formation of a one-year transition Government. Parliamentary and presidential elections were scheduled for July 1992 but political violence disturbed the electoral calendar, paralyzing economic activity from November 1992 through July 1993. The political situation improved during the second half of 1993. In August 1993, President Eyadema was reelected for a five-year term and legislative elections were completed in March 1994. 2.5 Economic Developments. The combination of socio-political turmoil and compression of Government expenditures, exacerbated by the drying up of foreign aid, led to a severe contraction of the economy. During 1991-93, GDP fell by 17 percent, revenues dropped by 47 percent, and by end-1993, the overall fiscal deficit widened to 14.5 percent of GDP. During 1992-93, the
 Education Rehabilitation Project 3 Government increase of domestic payment arrears amounted to about CFAF 37 billion (10% of GDP). The substantial drop in net foreign financing led to a marked deterioration in the overall balance of payments. By end-1993, external payment arrears amounted to the equivalent of US$ 111 million. 2.6 Post Devaluation Developments. The devaluation of the CFA Franc in January 1994, the formation of a new Government in June 1994 and the preparation of a three-year Policy Framework Paper (PFP) set the stage for greater political stability and the country's economic recovery. The 1994/95-1996/97 PFP provides the macroeconomic framework required for the resumption of structural reforms interrupted by the political turmoil of the last three years. During 1994, the economy showed clear signs of recovery and real growth is estimated to about 11 percent spurred by increased production of traditional export crops (cotton and coffee) and a strong recovery of mining and manufacturing. The external current account deficit was limited to 8 percent of GDP. The current primary budget deficit was contained to about 5 percent of GDP. However, despite improved performance in 1994, Government revenues amounted to only about half Government expenditures. Togo's budgetary situation is expected to remain tight in 1995, 1996 and 1997. C. Education Sector Background 1. Structure 2.7 Togo's education system consists of a six-year cycle of primary education, a four-year lower-secondary cycle, a three-year upper-secondary cycle, and a range of higher education programs from two to eleven years in length at the University of Benin. The Ministry of National Education and Scientific Research (MENRS) is responsible for general education programs; the Ministry of Technical Education and Vocational Training (METFP) is responsible for vocational training. The organization of the formal education system is presented in Annex I. 2. Administration 2.8 Operations within the two ministries are highly centralized: while regional offices for educational planning and school mapping exist, they are branches of the corresponding central structures. Togo's teaching corps is highly fragmented, with teachers falling into a number of separate categories for administrative purposes. The University of Benin has semi-autonomous status within the MENRS and receives a block grant for payment of operational expenditures and teachers. Approximately 66 percent of primary and secondary school teachers have regular civil service status. In addition to the 15,668 teachers and administrators with civil service status, (this figure includes 2,400 teachers in church-run schools for whom the Government pays 80 percent of civil service salary rates), approximately 4,300 auxiliary teachers are hired on a contract basis through a variety of Government programs and local initiatives: (a) the Ministry of Labor manages a " national service" training and employment program (Programme d'emploi et formation--PEF) under which approximately 1,400 primary teachers, 330 lower-secondary teachers, and 565 upper-secondary teachers are hired on the basis of renewable, low-cost contracts (at 20 to 40 percent of civil service wage rates): (b) collectivities have hired teachers largely through parental contributions (approximately 1,355 primary teachers); (c) inspectorates
 Education Rehabilitation Project 4 have paid auxiliary teacher salaries with funds generated in part from school fees and intended for their travel and operating budgets; and (d) parents' groups have hired teachers independently (at pay rates averaging between 5 to 10 percent of civil service rates). 2.9 Auxiliary primary school teacher salaries vary widely: locally hired teachers average approximately CFAF 7,000 monthly, although some receive no cash payments and are paid in kind. Underqualified teachers on Government contracts receive CFAF 20,000 monthly; teachers with a four-year secondary certificate (brevet) receive CFAF 25,000 monthly and teachers with high school diplomas (baccalaureat) or above receive CFAF 30,000 monthly. This compares to an average of CFAF 90,000 monthly for starting civil service teachers, including benefits. Secondary school teachers on contract receive either CFAF 65,000 or 70,000 monthly depending on qualifications. This is about one half of civil service rates for beginning secondary teachers, including benefits. 3. Sector Development Issues 2.10 Unplanned and unsustainable sector development. Since 1984, recruitment of civil servants in Togo has been frozen. In the education sector, this has given rise to a number of alternative and sometimes makeshift arrangements as described above, in order to replace retired or deceased teachers or to meet growing demand. These arrangements have been extremely unstable, and have resulted in school closings and frequent disruption of school programs and occasional strikes. The present fiscal crisis has exacerbated these problems, with the most severe problems created in rural areas, because urban schools more easily attract civil service teachers from rural areas to replace retiring teachers. 2.11 The economic crisis caused a serious deterioration in the quality and access to basic education, which was, even before 1990, characterized by inadequate budgetary allocations, inefficiency, and lack of relevance to the needs of a developing economy. At a functional level, many classrooms were severely overcrowded and teacher training was non-existent. The work of inspectors, directors and other personnel was organized in ways that provided almost no instructional support. Primary school enrollment ratios had been deteriorating, as had most indicators of instructional quality. At 36 percent and 46 percent respectively, student repetition and drop-out rates were among the highest in sub-Saharan Africa, and a disproportionately low number of girls were in school. There were systemic biases in favor of urban schooling, and in favor of higher levels of education. Secondary school teachers were often inefficiently distributed and underutilized. In general, policy making has been a highly centralized process. 2.12 The general strike in 1992-93 brought the educational system to a complete halt for six months, and further weakened a sector that had already been in steady decline for more than a decade. Following the strike, although classes have resumed, educational material is lacking, many auxiliary teachers recruited by the commnunities are still not being paid and instructional standards continue to fall as a result of a significant cut in inspectors' budgets and increased reliance on untrained teachers. While the situation is serious across the country, it is particularly acute in the Savannah and Central regions.
 Education Rehabilitation Project 5 2.13 Rural/urban disparities. A number of features within the current Togolese education system mitigate against equal schooling opportunities for rural children. The freeze on hiring teachers through the civil service has meant that as teachers retire in urban areas, there is a tendency that they are replaced by teachers from rural schools. This leaves the rural schools with a perennial teacher shortage, with no other recourse than to finance teachers with whatever sources of funding are available locally (parents' comrnittees, inspectors' travel and operational budgets, NGOs, etc.). In the rural Savannah region, for instance, 41 percent of all teachers are financed locally, whereas only 17 percent of teachers are financed locally in the capital city of Lome. The result is uneven teaching quality for children in rural areas, and significantly fewer opportunities to attend school and to advance through the grades. The net schooling rate in the country is estimated at 61 percent (1993-94), although statistical data are not reliable and enrollment rates vary from approximately 85 percent in the capital region to only 30 percent in the rural Savannah region. The lack of school mapping capacity has been a handicap to efforts to establish a sector expansion program sensitive to gender equity concerns. The lack of school mapping capacity further hinders the development of rural schooling. 2.14 Gender equity. The nation's female literacy rate is substantially lower than that among men (31 percent versus 52 percent). In rural areas the situation is worse as less than 15 percent of women are literate. The percentage of female students in the educational system remained low, and relatively unchanged, over the period 1980-90. The most striking feature concerning girls' schooling is that initial enrollment of girls is relatively positive (42 percent of the total), but that girls drop out of the system at astonishingly high rates: by the first year of secondary schooling, they represent only 29 percent of the total; by the last year of secondary schooling this figure has dropped to 12 percent. It is clear that the impact of Togo's high repetition rates is bome disproportionately by the female students, for whom repetition commonly leads to dropout. In several respects, the economic crisis has increased gender disparities. Female students have been less likely to return to school after the end of the strike. The findings of recent Bank sector work on girls' schooling in Togo will provide an important input for the quality school initiatives of the project, as well as future interventions in this area. Some demand and household-related factors affecting girls' schooling and the links between girls' schooling and school quality would require further operation-based study. 2.15 Budget and finance issues. The institutional capacity of the Ministry of Education for budget planning is weak. Resource allocation within the sector does not match the stated priorities of the Government. The education sector's share of the national budget has dropped from 28 percent to 19 percent, slightly below the francophone average for Sub-Saharan Africa of 22 percent; higher education receives about 25 percent of this total (1995) even though it serves only 1 percent of the students. Secondary education receives 34 percent of the total, while primary education receives a relatively low 41 percent of the overall sector budget. Education budget indicators are presented in Annex II. 2.17 The breakdown of the budget by expenditure category reveals a number of imbalances. Prior to the current economic crisis, salary expenditures in the primary education budget, for instance, consumed approximately 98 percent of total non-administrative expenditures, leaving very little for the purchase of textbooks, chalk, and other pedagogical inputs. The situation has
 Education Rehabilitation Project 6 further deteriorated since then, with non-salary operating expenditures now accounting for less than one percent of primary expenditures (excluding central administration). 2.18 Quality of instruction. There are a wide range of quality issues as regards teaching and learning outcomes requiring immediate attention. The repetition rate is the most striking indicator demonstrating the extent of the problem: fully 35 percent of all students in the system, at all levels from primary to tertiary, fail each year. Few textbooks are available, pre-service training has not been offered in ten years, and there is little in-service training. Adequate information regarding the quality of teaching and learning is unavailable. Statistical yearbooks are being produced almost three years late; evaluation capacity remains weak. At present, there is no capacity for systematically sampling the level of student learning outcomes, although evaluations of the system prepared in the mid- and late-1980s already referred to declining levels of performance. Many classrooms are overcrowded, with students numbering as high as 200 in urban Grade 1 classrooms. Annex m provides enrollment and repetition figures for primary and lower secondary education. 4. Government Education Sector Strategy 2.19 The evolution of Togo's education system has been the product of a complex interaction of factors, not all of which can be addressed at once. Immediately prior to the strike, MENRS established its priorities for the reform process in a Letter of Education Sector Policy. It emphasized basic education (Grades 1 through 10) and efforts to improve school quality and girls' participation. The principal management approach for achieving this was to be through a focus on the individual school as the locus of change. The Government also expressed a strong interest in exploring the possibility of decentralizing most sector management functions to the regional and prefectoral levels as a part of this shift in emphasis to the school level. 2.20 Following the strike, circumstances have forced the Government to redefine its priorities in order to address the most pressing crises in the sector. It has prepared and submitted to IDA a new Letter of Education Sector Policy (Annex IV) which highlights the lack of teachers and teaching materials, and the degradation of school facilities and proposes a two phase approach to educational reform. In the first phase, the Government seeks to restore stability to the sector by: (i) assuring the regular payment of all primary teachers; (ii) conducting a functional audit of the Ministry to ensure the best use of available personnel and resources to support teaching and learning, (iii) rehabilitating classrooms; and (iv) increasing the availability of basic pedagogic materials in conjunction with the implementation of experimental quality schools initiatives. 2.21 In parallel, during the first phase, the Government would develop mechanisms to put in place a more decentralized system of management and financing for primary education, including establishing five regional school boards and a decentralized Education Support Fund. Beyond its role as a conduit for the funding of auxiliary teachers' salaries, the Fund is seen as a tool for enabling more decentralized management of schools by regional school boards. Financing of the Fund would be the joint responsibility of communities and the Government, with the Government continuing to contribute most of the funding, in part through cost savings from attrition in the civil service, on an increasing basis. Community financing during this phase would initially consist of 40 percent of school fees, the proportion of school fees that is currently being transferred to the
 Education Rehabilitation Project 7 central Ministry. The Government would also seek donor financing to the Education Support Fund. 2.22 In the second phase of reform, the Government would move formally toward decentralized personnel management with the establishment of regional auxiliary teaching bodies. The regional school boards would take over responsibility for teacher recruitment and financing (with continuing Government contributions), in-service teacher training, as well as the development of initiatives at the regional and school levels to improve the quality of teaching and learning that would allow the expansion of access to primary and lower secondary schooling and substantive improvements in instructional quality. The Government has presented to IDA a signed Letter of Education Sector Policy a draft of which was discussed and agreed during negotiations. 5. World Bank Sector Strategy 2.23 The current project would address issues dealing with the first phase of the Government's strategy. This includes a start to establishing a framework for the gradual transfer of management responsibilities to the regions, a process which would be pursued under a follow-up operation. The follow up operation would continue to support local management of teaching and learning processes, as well as financial management and re-allocation of resources in a manner consistent with the Government's emphasis on basic education. Activities proposed under the current project have been designed in line with the two phase strategy and would prepare the ground for key aspects of the follow-up project, notably to provide improved management tools to the education system and a basic framework for longer-term decentralization of education management. The timing of the follow-up project would be determined in large part by success in implementing the activities planned in the present project, as well as by Government's ability to ensure sustainable funding of the sector. 2.24 The project would ensure the availability of teachers, teaching materials, and classrooms. The Education Ministry would be given assistance in establishing the criteria under which funding would be granted to regional school boards, as well as procedures for transfer of funds, accounting, auditing, etc. Financial managers would be trained for these school boards and financial accounts and procedures would be established for each region. School and community personnel would be trained to establish transparent procedures for managing the textbook rental program, the rehabilitation of classrooms, the redeployment of secondary school teachers,and the implementation of the Quality Schools Initiative to upgrade teaching quality. 2.25 In addition, the project would ensure the establishment of five decentralized school boards, with responsibility for hiring and firing auxiliary teachers, and funding granted according to agreed criteria, accounting and audit procedures. Redeployment of secondary school teachers would reduce the need for auxiliary teachers at this level and free up resources for primary education. The rehabilitation and replacement of 800 classrooms, the distribution of textbooks, and the extension of the Quality Schools Initiative would continue to provide for the improvement of teaching and learning.

Educational Management 2.26 A positive development in the evolution of management capacity within the MENRS has already' occurred with the establishment of a sectoral Steering Committee comprised of key departmental directors and chaired by the Minister or his representative. It was established to take responsibility for project preparation and implementation, and has emerged as the principal decision-making body within the ministry, with broad responsibility for policy decisions and implementation. The Steering Committee is the primary vehicle for ensuring that information and policy options produced during project implementation are effectively channeled into the policy formulation process. In this context, it is also responsible for ensuring wide participation in the preparation and implementation process, both within and outside the education ministry, and for building consensus regarding project objectives and operational strategies. 2.27 Given the importance of intersectoral re-allocation of resources in favor of the social sectors, and the need for a Government-wide dialogue regarding the links between education and economic development, an interministerial committee has been established to oversee these broader issues. Membership includes the Ministries of Education, Plan, Finance, and Employment The interministerial committee would meet on a quarterly basis during the first year of implementation and twice a year throughout the remaining years of the project. It would also provide annual updates to the Government's Letter of Education Sector Policy reflecting progress in ensuring the transition toward activities planned for the follow-up project. The interministerial committee would also be responsible for assuring the proposed reallocation of Government resources in favor of education. 2.28 Donor coordination. Among donors, IDA has taken the lead in the policy dialogue with Government. Discussions have been held with all of the principal actors who have historically been active in the sector, although some donors have suspended activities in the country. The African Development Bank (AfDB) has intervened in the VET subsector to rehabilitate three lower secondary vocational training centers; it has also begun to gradually replace 360 classrooms in the central region of the country. The European Union is also considering providing support to the primary education sector. The Japanese Governnent has already purchased library books and is considering the construction of a number of primary classrooms in urban areas. D. Lessons Learned 2.29 The Bank's previous involvement in the education sector in Togo underscores the need to pay attention to how the broad policy environment affects issues of implementation, sustainability and quality. Both the Educational Improvement Project (Education Project II) and the ongoing Vocational Education and Training Project provide compelling examples of these concerns. The lack of a coherent strategy to deal with insufficient funding of recurrent costs, especially for teacher financing has been a key issue. This created an unstable and unproductive teacher situation at all levels of the system and led to widespread teacher shortages. Project Objectives and Scope 3.1 Objectives and Scope. The project seeks to halt the degradation in educational services in Togo and strengthen institutional capacity conducive to developing longer-term reform. It does this by focusing interventions in two areas: (a) improving the quality of schools through school construction and rehabilitation, textbook provision, and the introduction of a school-based innovation in teaching and learning processes through the Quality Schools Initiative; and (b) developing better education system management through decentralized recruitment and financing of teachers and development of system management tools. With regard to better schools, the project would: (i) rehabilitate approximately 800 classrooms, many of which were damaged or vandalized during the ten-month period when Government virtually ceased to function in 1992- 93; (ii) finance the purchase of approximately 2,300,000 primary school textbooks and 41,000 primary teachers' guides, and approximately 510,000 lower secondary textbooks (Grades 7-10), and 20,000 lower secondary teachers' guides, along with training on textbook use and textbook stock maintenance; and (iii) lay the foundation for much greater school-level involvement in developing more effective teaching and learning processes (Quality Schools Initiative). With regard to better system management, the project would: (i) ensure the availability of teachers at the primary school level by helping stabilize the current auxiliary teacher situation; (ii) improve decision-making processes by strengthening information and communication systems; (iii) overhaul the process of preparing, monitoring, and executing the operating and investment budgets; and (iv) consolidate gains from an earlier Ministerial restructuring by focusing Ministry functions around the teaching and learning process. 3.2 Technical Assistance, Studies and Training. Only short-term technical assistance is envisaged under this project (about 250 man/months). The strategy adopted is to recruit high caliber expertise with a commitment to on-the-job training and the ability to transfer skills and knowledge to nationals (see details in Annex V and Annex XII). The consultant profiles developed emphasize the importance of training, team building and communication skills. In those instances where technical assistance is envisaged in the preparation of studies, the terms of reference call for close collaboration with Togolese counterpart professionals, including Togolese consultant firms and university personnel. Draft terms of reference for all technical assistance during the first year of the project have been agreed upon during negotiations.

Improve the Quality of Schools 3.3 In spite of the overall degradation of the sector, there have been some signs of improvement at the central level. A sectoral Steering Committee with substantial authority has been created and has become a strong decision-making body. Government Letter of Education Sector Policy demonstrates an understanding on the part of the Government that creating better schools means not only providing the proper mix of physical and pedagogical inputs, but also paying close attention to how change occurs. It reflects the Govermnent's comniitment to collect and disseminate reliable information about learning processes and learning outcomes, and to establish an enabling policy environment. 3.4 These positive developments stand in stark contrast to classroom-level realities, where the learning environment has been severely strained by the recent social and political unrest. Physical plants degraded rapidly due to vandalism and neglect which took place during the 1992-93 general strike. School materials were stolen or damaged, and instructional leadership was greatly diluted as inspectors' budgets disappeared or were assigned elsewhere and school principals were obliged to spending an increasing portion of their time dealing with new administrative challenges such as raising funds for hiring auxiliary teachers or for purchasing basic teaching and learning materials. 3.5 In addition to the insufficiency of the physical plant, there is little shared understanding among practitioners about how to improve the way schools operate. This is due in part to the lack of capacity to define evaluation criteria and to collect and analyze information on school-level performance. Little reliable information exists regarding student achievement, the performance of teachers and school managers, and the impact of education policy and strategic interventions on schools, teachers, and communities. (c) Quality Schools Initiative Component (base cost US$3.6 million equivalent) 3.14 Objectives and Scope. The implementation of the Education Improvement Project in Togo showed that for in-service education programs to be successfully translated into changed teacher behavior, they must match the felt needs of teachers in a consistent manner over time. However, in Togo, in-service training programs have been very top-down in nature, and have been implemented only sporadically. The teachers who have stood in greatest need of these programs, i.e. the village-based auxiliary teachers, have frequently not had access to them. Existing programs have often failed entirely to account for local variations in teacher and student
 Education Rehabilitation Project 13 needs. The Quality Schools Initiative component designed under the current operation seeks to address this weakness by supporting stakeholder involvement in designing and carrying out an innovative program of in-service training based on needs expressed by teachers themselves. This program builds on existing structures to introduce teaching innovations, and would help transform the role of the inspectors from one of administrative control to one of instructional support and leadership. 3.15 The Togolese school system has been growing progressively weaker largely because of the absence of adequate training for teachers. Both the pre-service and in-service training programs were suspended during the late-1980's because of a lack of funds. Under this component, in- service training would be re-introduced into the Togolese school system as the operational means by which the trend of declining quality would be reversed. It would be a school-based program, since this approach has been shown in studies elsewhere to have by far the greatest potential for leading to positive and lasting change in teacher behavior. In order to facilitate implementation, the component has been structured around three sub-components: (i) 50 cutting-edge demonstration schools would be home to action research activities; (ii) 300 schools would receive small grants given on a competitive basis for teacher-designed approaches to improving teaching and learning; and (iii) school-based in-service teacher training programs would be organized for all teachers throughout the country (including contractual teachers and teachers in private schools). The dissemination strategy is that the 50 demonstration schools would share results with the 300 "small grants" schools, each of which would in turn share results with another 8-10 schools, thus reaching all of the primary schools throughout the country. These results would in turn inform the in-service training program, giving it a solid grounding in school-based experience and research. Each of these sub-components is described briefly below. Their implementation would be coordinated by the DIFOP and in collaboration with the DEPD. 3.16 Action research schools. A series of school-based "action research" projects would be developed at 50 primary schools located in each of Togo's five geographic regions. Schools would be chosen based on both the presence of innovative personnel and the existence of promising local practices. To the extent possible, experimentation would build on local practices. Examples of innovations to be considered include decentralized teacher supervision and management systems, leading to a restructured role for school directors and inspectors, as well as an increased role of communities in school management. 3.17 Schools hosting "action research" programs would be provided with resources such as books and materials that could be replicated on a wider scale in the near term. The emphasis would be on experimenting with pedagogical practices at the school level that do not imply an important increase in recurrent spending. Improvements in the quality of learning and the performance of individual schools would be measurable in terms of exam success rates and lower repetition and drop-out rates. The process of pilot school identification and survey design would provide a vehicle for consensus and capacity building in terms of how to go about improving the way schools operate. The Quality School subcommittee (of the overall Steering Committee) would be responsible for selecting and orienting school survey/research teams. The larger "action research" projects would be selected through a competitive bidding process, in which public, quasi-public (including the university and NGOs) and private research-oriented institutions would be invited to submit survey proposals.

This initiative would help the MENRS to ensure stakeholder participation in designing a program of qualitative innovations and reform at the classroom level. The emphasis would be on practices having a direct impact on improving teaching and learning systems, highlighting three aspects in particular: (a) problem-solving approaches to teaching, (b) instructional management, and (c) the relationship between the school curriculum and the school context. It would initially be designed to deal almost exclusively with helping teachers modify their teaching strategies in the light of the new textbooks to be made available. In particular, inspectors in the chosen prefectures would work closely with the survey teams. Develop Better Education System Management 3.22 The process of preparing operating and investment budgets in the MENRS tends to be driven by ad hoc administrative concerns rather than functional priorities. MENRS staff have also been unable to define and articulate standard operating norms and spending priorities that would allow them to project the implications of various actions and spending options for decision makers either within the MENRS or in the central ministries (Finance, Planning, and Public Service). The major recurrent cost associated with the project will be auxiliary teachers' salaries. As explained in paragraphs 3.25-3.29, the project makes comprehensive arrangements to ensure the availability of stable sources of financing for salaries compatible with Government's overall resource outlook. Other recurrent costs generated by project investments have three implications. The first recurrent cost implication of project investments is the appropriate maintenance of textbook supplies. Government would also provide a separate budget line for renewal of primary textbooks, and would include this cost in its annual budget provisions. The second recurrent cost implication relates to the continued support for implementing the pedagogical practices developed under the Quality Schools Initiative that provide for better and more effective schools. These innovations support the development of mechanisms for building the capacity of school-level actors to organize and manage school programs effectively, thus developing a better sense of ownership and commitment to school quality and efficiency. This, in turn, would result in improved student learning and overall increases in efficiency. The initial cost of these activities will be financed by the project, then their sustainability would require further support from the Government and school resources. The third recurrent cost implication relates to the cost of upkeep and maintenance of school infrastructure. The cost for regularly maintaining the classrooms replaced and rehabilitated under the project is estimated at CFAF 45.0 million over five years; which would be shared by communities through labor contribution as well as Government through the provision of materials.

V. PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Benefits 5.1 The main benefits of the proposed project would be improved education quality and access as a result of a more adequate supply of primary school teachers, rebuilding of infrastructure badly damaged by recent vandalism and neglect, and greater availability of pedagogic materials at the primary and secondary school levels. The institutional capacity building carried out under the project will be an essential step for ensuring the presence of teachers in classrooms and for reversing declining enrollment trends. The establishment of consultative regional school boards and a region-based Education Support Fund in parallel with regional non- civil service teaching bodies, will present the potential for a significant reduction in unit salary costs as well as a corresponding opportunity for increasing the number of teachers in place and for reallocating the sectoral budget in favor of needed non-salary operating expenditures. B. Risks and Measures to Address Them 5.2 The main risks of the project are the politically unstable environment which could significantly increase the likelihood of implementation delays and difficulties in assuring adequate budgetary resources to finance Government's counterpart contribution including payment of auxiliary teachers. Other risks to achievement of project objectives are Government's capacity to address broad institutional, finance and political issues critical to the success of the refonn program and low sectoral capacity to oversee the Quality Schools Initiative on an ongoing basis. The risks presented by the politically unstable environment are addressed to some extent in project design, with an emphasis on working teams supported by coordinated short-tern interventions of extemal expertise. Budgetary issues are addressed through up-front agreement on budget targets that are included in Goverrnent's Letter of Education Sector Policy and that will be monitored through a planned Public Expenditure Review, and annual budget reviews. The Government's commitment to address institutional capacity issues has been expressed through its Letter of Education Sector Policy which includes specific institutional reform targets; these would be closely monitored throughout project implementation. The issue of low sectoral capacity to oversee the Quality Schools Initiative would be addressed through the use of short-term consultancies to provide training and research experience to Ministry and University of Benin personnel, who would in tum provide training to inspectors and pedagogic counselors on an ongoing basis. Within the framework of a global development strategy consistent with its macroeconomic and sector policy, the Togolese Government adopted an Education and Training Sector Policy Statement on May 12, 1993. The strategy to be implemented emphasizes primary education and is geared to improving the quality of the instruction provided. PRESENT SITUATION 2. Since 1975, the Togolese Government has been making major efforts within the framework of education reform to adapt the school system to the country's current situation and to make it truly democratic and efficient. However, given the sector's structural, organizational and financial difficulties, it has not been possible for all of the goals of the refonn process to be attained. In the mid-eighties, a combination of rapidly escalating school enrollments and a serious decline in Togo's economic and financial situation plunged the education sector into a crisis that the
 38 ANNEX IV Page 2 of 7 sociopolitical circumstances of recent years have exacerbated, seriously compromising the quality of education. The net primary enrollment rate, which was up to an acceptable level of 71 % by 1980 thanks to the reforms by then in place, has today dropped to 61.4%. 3. The Government made a significant effort to increase education financing during a period of widespread economic crisis. In 1988-89, education financing was up to CFAF 22.2 billion from 12.5 billion in 1979-80. However, this positive trend could not be maintained because of the economic constraints caused by the socio-economic crisis which had started in 1970. Also, the budgetary restrictions linked to the Structural Adjustment Programs since 1982 have resulted in reducing by 32% the part of the budget earmarked for the education sector, and allocations have increased at a slower rate than previously and by comparison to the budget as a whole. Also, the school system at all levels suffered from annual cuts in the share of the budget allocated to non- salary operating expenditures, which fell from 13% in 1978 to 6% in 1985-89 and to 1% in 1994- 95. With the serious financial difficulties of 1992-93, education expenditure fell to 18% of overall current expenditure. The January 1994 devaluation of the CFA franc dealt the final blow to the education system's weakened finances, pushing up the costs of school supplies and tuition fees, despite the Government's efforts to mitigate the impact of the devaluation. 4. As a result of the reform of education policies and programs, it became possible to identify the constraints in terms of infrastructure, human resources, and finances that were standing in the way of steady progress toward quality education. 5. The inadequate capacity of the schools to accommodate a school-age population that is constantly growing as demographic pressure increases is one of the factors preventing Togo's education system from developing satisfactorily. At present, 39% of school-age children are not attending school; they will never have a chance to do so if this situation continues. To solve this problem, the rural communities have been setting up more and more schools on their own initiative each year, a fact that the Government can no longer ignore. Most of the schools are operating under highly undesirable conditions: (i) buildings that are only half built or in serious disrepair; (ii) insufficient numbers of desks; (iii) classes with huge numbers of students (100-150 students per class, particularly at the primary level); (iv) shortage of teaching materials; (v) teachers with little or no training and little motivation. 6. Because of the civil service hiring freeze ordered by the Government in 1982 as a result of the economic crisis, the Ministry of National Education and Scientific Research was unable to replace teachers who had died or retired. At the primary school level, the impact of this hiring freeze was felt throughout all regions of the country, but it was the rural areas that suffered the most. To cope with the staff shortage, parents recruited substitute teachers, paying them out of their own meager funds. Those teachers thus received non-scale and highly variable wages. In 1992, the Government took over the payment of some of these auxiliary teachers, but still at wage levels far below the civil service pay scale. Most of the auxiliaries are still poorly paid and severely lacking in motivation. Of this group, 37% are paid by the Government under a job training program, at a monthly rate of CFAF 25,000, while the rest are paid by parents and local communities at an average rate varying between CFAF 5,000 and CFAF 8,000. Taking advantage of recent political movements, the auxiliary teachers have begun to demand that their situation be regularized, specifically through their admission into the civil service.
 ANNEX IV Page 3 of 7 But the Government is of the opinion that the admission of auxiliary teachers into the civil service is no longer feasible, and that a new hiring policy is called for in this area. Auxiliary teachers are also found at the lower and upper secondary levels, where the same hiring freeze has created a problem that is less serious but similar to that being experienced at the primary level. Auxiliary teachers account for 25% of the teaching staff in the lower and upper secondary schools. 7. In an atmosphere of political change, when various demands are being voiced, the teachers in this category have become aware of their importance within the system. Their number is continually growing because of the sector's enormous demands, and today there are 4,950 such auxiliaries (across the entire system), all of whom are demanding that their situation be regularized, specifically through admission into the civil service, a movement that is seriously jeopardizing the school system's normal operation. 8. These constraints are found throughout our country's education system, and are jeopardizing both its internal and external efficiency. As in primary education, the problems hampering operation of the system at the lower and upper secondary levels derive from: (i) the huge numbers of students in the classrooms, particularly in the large urban areas; (ii) the relatively few permanent teachers in relation to auxiliaries without status (15% at the lower secondary level and 45% at the upper secondary level); (iii) the inadequacy of teaching materials and textbooks in the schools; (iv) the lack of scientific equipment for experiments; (v) the lack of financing for the schools set up by local communities. At the higher education level, the University of Benin is suffering shortages in the areas of infrastructure, teaching staff, boarding facilities and research. Suspension of bilateral cooperation agreements has led to the departure of the expatriates and brought a halt to actions and assistance under the heading of bilateral cooperation. The result has been the freezing of several ongoing projects and programs. The various student groups that have come into being over the past few years are staging strikes and other types of demonstrations to support their demands for increased scholarships. NEW SECTOR STRATEGY 9. To cope with all these constraints, and in light of the macroeconomic objectives for 1996-97 and of its Sector Policy Statement adopted in 1993, the Government is committed to implementing a global education and training strategy based on the following five new points: (i) improving the internal and external efficiency of the education system, focusing in particular on primary education; (ii) increasing intake capacity; (iii) improving human resource allocation and utilization; (iv) strengthening the system's capacity for decentralized management through the establishment of Regional Directorates of Education; and (v) consolidating the sector's financial position through allocation of an appropriate level of resources. 10. The Government's sector development policy will emphasize primary education, with a net enrollment target of 80% of the school-age population in the years 2000-2010.
 40 ANNEX IV Page 4 of 7 To this end, the Government intends to encourage the private sector to play a more active role in the development of primary education in general and of the pre-school level in particular, for which support is already being received from UNICEF. In addition, the Government will take all necessary action to encourage religious schools to restructure and develop so that they can play a more active role in the efforts being made in this field. The Government will continue to provide technical support to the religious and commnunity schools to improve teacher quality and infrastructure safety, so that the agreed targets may be attained. IMPROVEMENT OF EFFICIENCY AND OF INTAKE CAPACITY 11. In the context of improvement of the education system's internal and external efficiency and increasing of its intake capacity, the Government will take the necessary steps to enable each child to successfully complete his/her primary education so that he/she will be able to function harmoniously in the socioeconomic environment. To this end efforts will be made in each level of education to render them more efficient. Accordingly, at the Primary level the Government intends to allocate the necessary means to ensure: (i) provision of textbooks at low cost to students and of teaching materials for teachers; (ii) enhancement of the status of women by means of girls'education and training; (iii) training and recruitment of teachers for classes currently without any; (iv) intensification of the pedagogic supervision of teachers; (v) rehabilitation of school buildings, furnishing them with chairs, boards, desks: and (vi) improvement of the quality of existing community schools. For general Secondary Education, the measures to be taken will focus on: (i) improvement of the student-teacher ratio; (ii) provision of textbooks and teaching materials; (iii) more and better equipment for the scientific and technical education establishments; (iv) teacher training and refresher training; and (v) setting up of an effective student and vocational orientation structure at the school level. At the Higher Education level, science and technology are opening up new horizons as we move toward the twenty-first century. Togo is committed to setting up a higher education system capable of offering training programs of quality and of a competitive level in order to provide access to the new scientific and technological data. To this end, the Government will make a diagnostic study of the University of Benin in order to identify the dysfunctions and bottlenecks in the present structure and programs. The findings and conclusions of this study will open the way for a true reform of the programs with a view to professionalizing university education so that graduates will be better equipped and directly employable. The reform will focus essentially on the following fields: (i) regulation of access to the different areas of higher education; (ii) diversi- fication of higher education; (iii) development of scientific and research education infrastructures; (iv) intensification of institutions for training upper middle level personnel (IUTs) to meet the labor market's immediate needs; (v) establishment of a partnership between industries, the private institutions and the University of Benin with a view to professionalization of education; and (vi) pedagogic training of teachers.

Adaptation of the education system to the socioeconomic environment is an important component of the sector development policy, so that system graduates will be able to fit easily into the socioeconomic environment. To accomplish this the Government conmmits itself to: (i) define and create branches of training in accordance with the needs of the labor market; (ii) develop skills in students aimed at fostering entrepreneurship and private enterprise; (iii) arouse awareness arnong students and their parents regarding the needs of the priority sectors of the national economy; (iv) channel students toward the priority sectors; and (v) intensify practical training in all fields of education. BETTER ALLOCATION AND UTILIZATION OF SECTOR HUMAN RESOURCES 13. Since improvement of the quality of education is subject to, among other things, availability of sufficient teaching staff of adequate caliber, the Government will endeavor to improve the allocation and utilization of the system's human resources in light of the country's financial position and the need to reorganize the civil service. The actions envisaged in this connection are the following: 14. At the primary level. To implement this policy, the Government intends to create a corps of non-civil service auxiliary public school teachers whose particular status will be defined by regulatory texts. This policy will make it possible to increase the numbers of teachers to cover retirements, deaths, and such additional manpower that the sector may need in order to achieve the 80% enrollment rate projected for the period 2000-2010. These auxiliary teachers will be recruited per post. At the same time, and to ensure a minimum of stability within the education system (an essential condition for ensuring the quality of education), the Government will create an auxiliary teacher corps for personnel at all levels of the system. It will apply to the positions of teachers' aide [moniteur], primary school teaching assistant [instituteur-adjoint], and lower and upper secondary school teacher. 15. One of the Government's main concerns is the status of the auxiliary teachers and the financing of teachers in general. The available budget funds for the next five years are well below what would be needed to pay the wages of all of the auxiliary teachers. Large-scale expansion of the system to achieve the objective of providing schooling for at least 80% of school-age children between now and the period 2000-2010 will only be possible if the unit costs are reduced and if the donors provide an important financial assistance. Thus, this strategy will allow to ensure a minimum of stability for the education system. 16. To this end, the Government responded by creating an Education Support Fund to which the savings realized as a result of retirement or death will be paid so as to enable the sector to hire new auxiliary teachers. These savings on the wage bill will make it possible to defray the wages of the auxiliary teachers, according to the auxiliary teachers'status created for this purpose. The Fund will be financed both by the sector's internal resources, particularly by a percentage of school fees, contributions from the Parent Associations and local authorities, and budgetary resources that the
 42 ANNEX IV Page 6 of 7 Government may mobilize either out of the general budget or in the form of contributions from our donors and partners in development. In the medium term it will make it possible to experiment with the establishing of increasingly decentralized management and financing structures. 17. At the lower and upper secondary levels, the Government plans, to carry out before the end of 1996 a diagnostic study on the use of teaching staff at these two levels in order to assess the extent to which a combination of the two levels is likely to achieve better performance. In this context, following an assessment of the needs the teaching staff will be redeployed as soon as possible with the aim of reducing the number of auxiliary teachers in secondary education in favor of primary education. Moreover, the Government aims to realize efficiency gains through redeployment of personnel at the lower and upper secondary levels, imposing a weekly minimum of 21 classroom hours in the colleges and 18 in the lycees. 18. At the university level. The Government has already eliminated first-year scholarships in favor of across-the-board university aid. The diagnostic study will determine which other urgent methods are likely to enhance sector efficiency. 19. Since the key element of any efficient education system is the quality of the teachers'training, the Government will upgrade the professional qualifications of the teaching staff in service and will ensure the training of pedagogic support personnel. Also, auxiliary teachers at all levels will also be trained in teaching techniques and in action research to improve teaching quality. An advanced training program for teachers in general will be implemented by means of training courses and periodic refresher training in particular in specially designated training institutions. STRENGTHENING OF THE SECTOR'S MANAGEMENT CAPACITY 20. Strengthening of management capacity is an important component of the policy envisioned by the Government. To ensure sound functioning of the education system, achievement of this objective calls for establishment of a good mechanism for managing human, financial and material resources. The Government accordingly envisages a restructuring of the Ministry of Education and Scientific Research involving decentralization of the system's management and establishment of the Regional Directorates of Education. This restructuring will be accompanied by the following actions: special training of the administrative personnel in the new management techniques; setting up of an adequate mechanism for management of personnel, finances, equipment and infrastructure, at both central and regional level; periodic organization of internal audits; organization of monitoring and evaluation of programs/projects in execution in the system; and evaluation of sector performance by the beneficiaries. Implementation of a true decentralization policy can contribute to management of the education system by enabling the territorial authorities (Region, Prefecture, Commune) and the population at large to organize their own local development, geared to active participation by the local inhabitants in efforts to improve the quality of education. To this end it will be necessary to decide on the procedures for transferring capabilities to the Regional Directorates of Education, to define new functions for those Regional Directorates, and to
 43 ANNEX IV Page 7 of 7 put in place and upgrade their management capacities. The long-term objective is decentralization of management of the education system, with the establishment of a corps of regional teachers, with decentralized management of teaching posts in the region. However, the regional approach to the education system, i.e. that of decentralization as necessary, should be progressive, given the scarcity of financial resources and the large volume of human, material and financial resources this will involve. But in any case this approach can be implemented only with the support of our development partners. FINANCING OF THE SECTOR'S STRATEGY 21. The sector's financial position has deteriorated over recent years as a result of the combined effects of three factors: the impact of the structural adjustment programs, the adjustment of the exchange rate for the CFA franc, and the sociopolitical crisis. To resolve the financial crisis besetting the sector, the Government will mobilize real and potential local resources. This domestic effort will have to be supported by the contributions of development partners. 22. One of the important steps undertaken by the Government in this connection is establishment of an Education Support Fund, the resources of which will be formed by the contributions of the State, development partners, local authorities and private sector together with those of parents through school fees, the rate of which will be reformulated, harmonized and made generally applicable. In addition, the savings to be gained from staff leaving the civil service on account of retirement or death will be paid into the fund. The Fund' s resources will be used at first to pay the salaries of auxiliary teachers. 23. The Education Support Fund will be created by Presidential Decree issued in Council of Ministers. This decree will specify the role of the local authorities and how it is to be carried out taking into account local conditions as well as the opinion of involved Ministries. 24 The Government will undertake efforts to increase substantially the allocations of funds to the various education levels according to the objectives of its 1994-1997 medium-tern economic policy. Thus, by the end of the period 1996-98 the education budget will accordingly be back at the level of the order of 22% of the State budget it had reached in 1991. Capital expenditures in the education and training sector will be increased during the same period. The Government for its part undertakes to ensure that the fund is created and, further, to pursue the efforts to improve the quality of primary and secondary education by increasing the operating budget (exclusive of salaries), raising it to 20% of personnel expenditures during the period 1996-2001.  53 ANNEX VII Page 1 of 4 REPUBLIC OF TOGO EDUCATION REHABILITATION PROJECT QUALITY SCHOOLS INITIATIVE I. Background. The implementation of the Education II Project in Togo showed that for in- service education programs to be successfully translated into changed teacher behavior, they must match the felt needs of teachers in a consistent manner over time. However, in Togo, in- service training programs have been very top-down in nature, and implemented in inconsistent fashion. The teachers who have stood in greatest need of these programs, i.e. the village-based auxiliary teachers, have frequently not had access to these programs, which all too often have failed entirely to account for local variations in teacher and student needs. The Quality Schools Initiative designed under the current operation seeks to address this weakness by supporting stakeholder involvement in designing and carrying out an innovative program of in-service education based on needs expressed by teachers themselves. This program builds on existing structures to introduce teaching innovations, and would help transform the role of regional and prefectoral inspectors from one of administrative support to one of instructional support and leadership. I. PROGRAM OBJECTIVES 2. Long-term goals and objectives. The long-term goals of the Quality Schools Initiative are derived from Government's statement of education sector policy, i.e. to improve the quality of teaching and leaming in Togolese primary schools and to increase the level of community involvement in the education programs. This program would be the operational mechanism through which the school becomes the locus of change in the education system. As such, the program is seen, not as a permanent feature of the educational scene in Togo, but as a key transitional program over a five-year period, starting to redefine the role of teacher, principal, pedagogic advisor, and inspector. It would have the following long-term objectives: (a) to help teachers focus on improving subject matter teaching; (b) to improve the knowledge base of teachers; (c) to promote community involvement in school activities; (d) to develop a feedback loop permitting decision-makers to receive reliable information about the quality of teaching and learning; and (e) to introduce promising new approaches to teaching into the educational system. 3. Medium-term goals and objectives. The principal medium-term goals of the Quality Schools Initiative are to operationalize the Government's commitment to bringing about school- based change within Togolese primary schools and to pass the message of the need for qualitative change in teaching to all stakeholders. The medium-term objectives are the following: to help school personnel develop project proposals based on local school needs; to train inspectors and pedagogic advisors to provide instructional support to teachers and school directors; to develop community participation in the introduction of innovations; and to ensure financial responsibility in the use of funds.
 54 ANNEX VII Page 2 of 4 II. IMPLEMENTATION 4. Project description. The project will involve the following elements: (a) the introduction of innovative activities at the primary school level; (b) the use of action-research projects as a tool for innovation and in-service training; (c) the participation of schools and their communities for analysis of existing education problems and the development of tentative solutions; (d) the increased use of national expertise; (e) increasing decentralization of responsibilities to the regions; and (f) systematic follow-up of action-research and other school-level activities. 5. Proposals for school improvement will fall into one of two categories: action research projects and school/community projects. Approximately 300 small grants would be given on a competitive basis to individual schools or school clusters for improving teaching and learning. An additional 50 more broadly-based projects with external researchers (Ministry and university personnel) would also be financed. 6. Preparation of proposals. The process of pilot school identification and survey design would provide a vehicle for consensus and capacity building in terms of how to go about improving the way schools operate. The School Quality subcommittee (of the overall Steering Committee) would be responsible for selecting and orienting school survey/research teams. The small grants to individual schools or school clusters would be given on the basis of a proposals prepared by the school teachers and directors themselves. The larger "action research" projects would be selected through a competitive bidding process, in which public, quasi-public (including the university and NGOs) and private research-oriented institutions would be invited to submit survey proposals. A total of 72 small grants would be given during the first phase of the project. 7. Selection of proposals. Six selection committees (one in each of the five regions, and a national committee located in Lome) will meet once a year for selection of the proposals. The pre-selection at the regional level, and the final selection at the national level will be based on criteria described in the operational manual. These include, but are not limited to, the following: (a) the educational value of the proposed project, including its potential contribution to improving teaching and learning at the school and the potential benefit for target groups such as the poor, rural students, and girls; (b) the feasibility of the proposed project; (c) the capacities and potential of unit members; and (d) the level of community support for the proposal. 8. The program would begin with teams working in each of Togo's five geographic regions. Schools would be chosen based on both the presence of innovative personnel and the existence of promising local practices. To the extent possible, experimentation would build on local practices. Examples of innovations to be considered are: (a) decentralized teacher supervision and management systems, leading to a restructured role for school directors and inspectors, (b) monitoring of teacher candidates based on traditional apprenticeship models and private sector initiatives, and (c) increasing the role of communities in school management.
 55 ANNEX VII Page 3 of 4 9. Training programs. An in-service teacher training program is being developed under this component for training of all primary school teachers, based on the activities and results of the Quality Schools Initiative itself-.The in-service training strategies would be centered on and informed by the "action research" activities. It is further expected that the "action research" programs would stimulate the mobilization of additional resources at the community level. In addition, host schools would be expected to evolve into demonstration schools to be used for in- service training. 10. In the first two years of the project, the focus will be on the upgrading of auxiliary teachers (approximately 30 percent of the total number of primary school teachers). These teachers will receive a more intensive training program, but all teachers will receive a minimum of three days in-service training over the first two years (approximately 6000 teachers each year). Training seminars have already been held for the personnel who will form the central selection committee. This seminar will be repeated in each region of the country for training the regional selection committees and the program evaluators. While the program itself constitutes a significant in-service training experience, additional training for school directors, pedagogic advisors and inspectors will take place under the Ministerial Restructuring component of the project. The training programs are described in the operational manual. 11. Renewal of funding. School/community proposals will cover a one-year period with financing to range from $1000 to $3000. The best initiatives could be renewed for a second year or a third year, upon recommendation of the regional jury. 12. First phase of in-service education. This program is a key element of the Government's strategy for renewing in-service education over the project lifespan. The unit responsible for in- service training (DIFOP), the National Institute of Education Sciences (INSE), and the Elementary Education will participate in initial planning and training activities in order to harmonize the role of each of these entities in this program. II. EVALUATION AND FOLLOW-UP 12. Reports. The selection committees will prepare reports of their activities and decisions. Bi-monthly summaries of activities and expenses will be provided by the research units) for transmission to the regional level. An end-of-year report will be prepared by each research unit as per the criteria and issues outlined in the operational manual. 13. Managing the change process. In order to ensure that the lessons learned at the school level serve as a stimulus for the process of change in the country, regional seminars will be held each summer. They will bring together representatives of all groups funded during the previous year, as well as the other personnel associated with the program. The format will be that of a professional conference (break-out groups followed by a plenary session). Representatives of the action-research and the school/community groups will meet according to the themes they have dealt with; each group will discuss the generalizability of the results obtained. A national
 56 ANNEX VII Page 4 of 4 seminar will follow the regional seminars each year. Where appropriate, outside funding would be sought for innovative groups to present their findings at professional conferences outside the country. 15. The survey/research process would give the Steering Committee, as well as IDA and other donors, the opportunity to evaluate the capacity of the survey teams and to provide constructive feedback where needed. The number of schools involved in the program would expand depenrding on local capacity, resource availability, and results obtained. The Steering Committee would be responsible for ensuring that all activities--survey team selection, school selection, survey design preparation and survey implementation--are coordinated with the relevant regional and district-level authorities. In particular, inspectors in the chosen school districts would work closely with the survey tearns. 16. Satellite school arrangements and instructional supervision guidelines for school principals would be tested through the network of schools participating in the Quality Schools Initiative. The Quality Schools Initiative would also help the Government monitor expenditures within the framework of the education budget for routine teacher training and supervision. It would also evaluate the impact of training on teaching quality and student learning outcomes.

doc.abstracts: The Education Rehabilitation Project is designed to reverse the rapid deterioration in the education sector in Togo following several years of social and political unrest and a decade of declining enrollment and quality. The project has two objectives: to improve the quality of schools and to develop better education system management. The project comprises two components: 1) the development of better schools through school construction and rehabilitation, provision of textbooks, and the Quality of Schools Initiative; and 2) development of better education system management through decentralized recruitment and financing of teachers, development of system managment tools including information and communication systems, budgetary programming and monitoring, consolidation of the minsterial restructuring by strengthening decision-making process and further decentralizing the responsibility for instructional as well as financial management.
